PostValue.explanation: This is an interesting, provocative, and moderately important post for the EA/rationalist community because it highlights a neglected, potentially large-scale source of diminished wellbeing (digital addiction/suboptimal engagement), argues tractability via market-friendly interventions (better, non‑exploitative games), and raises important consistency questions about how EAs weigh many small welfare gains versus fewer lifesaving interventions. If the core claims were borne out, it could shift funding and research priorities and create new scalable interventions and revenue streams for other EA causes — but the empirical and moral claims are speculative and not foundational to EA’s major pillars (e.g., global health, bio/AI risk). For general humanity the post is of minor importance: tens/hundreds of billions of hours of modestly worse experiences would matter in the aggregate, but the per‑person harms are small, the causal claims and tractability are uncertain, and the proposal doesn’t threaten or protect near‑term existential outcomes. Overall, worth further empirical investigation and pilot interventions, but not a high‑stakes paradigm shift unless much stronger evidence appears.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Major unsupported quantitative claims and missing counterfactual model
- Problem: You lean on big numbers (hours, $/well‑being, conversion of game profits to bednets) and a Claude estimate without transparent modeling, citations, or sensitivity analysis. Those figures drive the headline comparison but are highly uncertain. Readers will dismiss the piece if the numbers aren’t reproducible. 
- Actionable fix: Add a short, explicit counterfactual model (even a simple spreadsheet style outline) showing your assumptions, data sources, and a 3‑scenario sensitivity analysis (pessimistic/median/optimistic). Cite studies on time spent in games/social media, empirical estimates of well‑being effects, and any market revenue breakdowns. Flag which numbers are guesses and why. If you can’t produce that model, drop the quantitative comparisons and make the piece qualitative and exploratory instead.

2) Tractability / market realism is under-argued (big strategic omission)
- Problem: You assume making “non‑exploitative” games that are profitable and displace predatory ones is tractable. This overlooks distribution costs, discoverability, network effects, user preferences for attention‑maximizing mechanics, and monetization tradeoffs (how to be profitable without dark patterns). It also assumes profits will be directed to EA causes. 
- Actionable fix: Add a realistic section addressing business model and go‑to‑market challenges: required marketing spend to reach mass markets, examples of wellbeing‑focused games that scaled (or failed), likely monetization strategies that avoid exploitation, and concrete failure modes (e.g., users switch to other addictions). If possible, include at least one case study/pilot or propose a testable pilot (RCT or A/B test) that would measure reach, retention, wellbeing impact, and profitability before making large claims.

3) Ethical comparability and priority framing needs sharpening
- Problem: The post raises the ’first‑world problems vs life‑saving’ tension but doesn’t apply a consistent ethical framework (DALYs/QALYs, marginal utility, priority to worst off). Without that, the implied moral parity between mild improvements for many and saving lives is unpersuasive. You also don’t address substitution effects (time freed might be used in other ways) or distributional concerns.
- Actionable fix: State explicitly which ethical metric you’re using (e.g., QALYs, utilitarian welfare units, or a rights‑based view) and show how the proposed intervention compares on that metric per dollar. Discuss diminishing marginal utility and the special weight of life‑saving interventions. Briefly rebut the strongest counterarguments (substitution of time, prestige/legitimacy costs for EA, risk of mission drift if profits fund other causes). If you want to keep the provocative tone, mark these as open tradeoffs and recommend concrete empirical steps to resolve them.

If you address these three points you’ll turn a provocative thought piece into a much more credible and publishable argument rather than an attention‑grabbing claim built on thin assumptions.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: The feedback catches the three most consequential weaknesses: unsupported headline numbers/counterfactuals, optimistic tractability/market assumptions, and a muddled ethical/prioritization framework. Each point is actionable (ask for a simple counterfactual model and sensitivity analysis, realistic go‑to‑market/failure modes or a pilot, and an explicit ethical metric), and fixing them would substantially raise the post’s credibility. It loses one point because the feedback could have also flagged smaller but important issues (e.g., transparency about AI assistance in the draft, clearer scope/definitions, and evidence around substitution effects beyond what’s implied) that would further reduce “own‑goal” risks.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: I have no record of 'Davidmanheim' being a well-known EA/rationalist figure in my training data (up to 2024-06). The name (or pseudonym) does not appear as a central speaker, frequent author, or widely-cited contributor on major EA/rationalist venues (LessWrong, EA Forum, 80,000 Hours, Open Phil), so they are likely low-profile or an occasional/pseudonymous contributor. Globally they appear to have essentially no public prominence. (I may be missing very recent or highly niche activity.)

PostClarity.explanation: Overall the post is readable, well-structured, and presents a provocative central claim: that improving digital systems could be a large, neglected, and tractable moral issue worth comparing to classic EA interventions. Strengths: clear thesis, logical sectioning (problem, scale, tractability, conclusions), and a conversational tone that invites discussion. Weaknesses: many empirical claims are vague or backed by handwavy estimates (e.g., '1–5 billion hours', Claude-derived cost–benefit numbers) and the mix of normative and empirical arguments is sometimes blurred, which weakens the persuasive force; asides (draft-amnesty, image joke, struck-through lines) and some repetition reduce concision. To improve clarity, tighten and source key quantitative claims, separate normative assumptions from empirical evidence, and end with a sharper summary of the argument and concrete proposals or questions for readers.

PostNovelty.explanation: Most of the component claims are familiar to EA readers: attention-economy harms, the moral tradeoff between large numbers of small well‑being improvements and life‑saving interventions, and using profitable enterprises to fund charity. What is moderately novel here is the concrete, provocative assembly — pitching non‑exploitative game development as a tractable, neglected EA-style intervention that could both reduce digital harm and generate fungible funding (i.e., the specific ‘better games vs bednets’ framing). For the general public this is less novel — worries about addictive games/social media and business‑funded charity are widespread — so the post is mainly a provocative recombination rather than a highly original idea.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: Strengths: The post identifies an underexamined, plausibly important problem (harmful/dark-pattern digital design), points to large-scale usage and revenues, and raises useful conceptual considerations (neglectedness, transferability, aggregation of small harms). Weaknesses: The core argument is highly speculative and under-specified. Key causal and counterfactual links are not established — e.g. that non‑exploitative games could displace harmful ones at scale, that they would be sufficiently profitable to fund high-impact work, or that aggregate welfare gains would compete with life‑saving interventions. Quantitative claims are often guesswork (wide hour estimates, unverified cost/benefit numbers from ‘Claude’), missing standard metrics (QALYs/DALYs, credible cost‑effectiveness comparisons to bednets), and ignore major practical obstacles (market incentives, user switching, monetization tradeoffs). Overall the piece is thought‑provoking but provides weak empirical support and only modestly sound reasoning for the bold claim that making games could rival classic global health interventions.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: Most of the post’s descriptive statistics are broadly plausible and supported by public data, but several important quantitative claims are rough estimates or speculative. Supported: (a) US gaming prevalence and high weekly hours (MarketingCharts/NPD), (b) very large global gamer population and plausible aggregate play-hours (Newzoo; global average hours/week ≈ 7–8 → yields multi‑billion hours/day), (c) social‑media scale and Facebook’s ≈3 billion MAUs. Supported evidence also shows microtransactions/loot‑boxes are associated with financial harm. Less well supported / overstated: the author’s $30–50B figure for “gacha/loot box revenue” appears higher than most market estimates (statista/data reports cluster ~ $18–22B in recent estimates), and mobile gaming revenue quoted as “~$100B” is within order-of-magnitude but depends on measurement method (Sensor Tower, Newzoo give lower/variable figures). Claims about the tractability (e.g., $1M→$3–10M redirected, or $10M to develop a mid‑tier game and exact reach/wellbeing returns) are speculative modelling rather than empirically validated. Overall: many major empirical building blocks check out, but some numbers are rough/optimistic and several causal/ROI claims are conjectural and unverified.

([statista.com](https://www.statista.com/statistics/273829/average-game-hours-per-day-of-video-gamers-in-selected-countries//?utm_source=openai))

Sensor Tower (State of Mobile Games Outlook 2024) and Newzoo — mobile game revenue estimates differ by methodology (Sensor Tower: $76.7B in 2023; Newzoo: mobile ≈ $90B range). Shows the author’s “~$100B” is a reasonable round‑figure but sensitive to source. ([sensortower.com](https://sensortower.com/blog/state-of-mobile-games-market-outlook-2024-report?utm_source=openai), [newzoo.com](https://newzoo.com/resources/blog/global-games-market-revenue-estimates-and-forecasts-in-2024?utm_source=openai))

Statista / market reports on loot boxes / gacha — estimates are notably lower than $30–50B; Statista forecasted ~US$17.8B (2021) and other market reports put the gacha/loot‑box/gacha markets in the low tens of billions (e.g., ~$20–23B), so $30–50B appears to be an overestimate. ([statista.com](https://www.statista.com/statistics/1240245/consumer-spending-loot-boxes-global-growth/?utm_source=openai), [datahorizzonresearch.com](https://datahorizzonresearch.com/gacha-games-market-38184?utm_source=openai))

MDPI / peer‑reviewed literature and Royal Society Open Science — studies linking loot boxes/microtransactions to problem gambling and financial/mental‑health harms (e.g., MDPI and R. Soc. Open Sci papers). ([mdpi.com](https://www.mdpi.com/2078-2489/14/7/399/xml?utm_source=openai), [royalsocietypublishing.org](https://royalsocietypublishing.org/doi/full/10.1098/rsos.220111?utm_source=openai))

Meta (Investor Relations Q4 2023) and platform usage summaries — Facebook (Meta family) MAUs ≈ 3.07B (Facebook MAU) and Family MAP ≈ 3.98B (Dec 2023 reporting). Average time‑on‑Facebook estimates ~30–35 min/day in some analytics summaries. ([investor.fb.com](https://investor.fb.com/investor-news/press-release-details/2024/Meta-Reports-Fourth-Quarter-and-Full-Year-2023-Results-Initiates-Quarterly-Dividend/default.aspx?os=vpkn75tqhopmkpsxtq&ref=app&utm_source=openai), [oberlo.com](https://www.oberlo.com/statistics/average-time-spent-on-facebook?utm_source=openai))

GiveWell / Against Malaria Foundation analyses — mass distribution of insecticide‑treated nets is highly cost‑effective; GiveWell estimates cost per death averted of roughly $3,000–$8,000 depending on location and model inputs (AMF per‑net costs and CEA). This supports the post’s claim that bednets are far more cost‑effective than small well‑being improvements in wealthy countries. ([givewell.org](https://www.givewell.org/international/technical/programs/insecticide-treated-nets?utm_source=openai))
